Thus, in the medium-term, the ethanol demand as renewable fuel or gasoline additive employed in Otto cycle motors will decrease in some countries, especially in Brazil. This event can foster the shift of Brazilian distilleries into real sugarcane-based biorefineries and, consequently, promote the production of many important chemicals from renewable feedstocks with emphasis on ethanol. Butadiene is generated as a by-product of the steam cracking process of naphtha or gas oil feedstocks. This process produces ethene and other olefins, being butadiene one of them. The nowadays use of lighter feedstocks which generate lower amounts of C4 compounds is increasing the relevance of the on-purpose processes of butadiene synthesis. Butadiene is a commodity that is mainly employed to synthesize rubbers and polymer resins. Styrene-butadiene rubber (SBR) and polybutadiene rubber (BR) are used in the manufacture of tires, whereas, acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene (ABS) to produce resins. Butadiene is employed in other polymers like styrene-butadiene latex, nitrile rubber and adiponitrile (ADN) which find many applications [1]. Ethanol began to be used as feedstock for the generation of chemicals in many countries in the early twentieth century. The ethyl chloride, acetic acid, ethyl ether, butadiene, and other chemicals were produced from this alcohol. Later, the majority of these processes were replaced by petroleum-based routes. It is worth mentioning two successful industrial processes related to the butadiene synthesis named as Lebedev and Ostromislensky, developed by Russia and US, respectively. The former employs only ethanol as raw material whereas the other ethanol plus acetaldehyde [2–5]. This olefin was used in the synthetic rubber production. Currently, the synthesis of butadiene from ethanol is one of the most studied themes in the ethanol chemistry field. The main driving forces for these researchers are the use of renewable feedstocks for chemicals production, the relevance of butadiene for the automotive industry and also the on-purpose process development for this olefin generation. The butadiene generation from ethanol shows the main characteristics of other chemicals syntheses which use this alcohol as feedstock. The most important points are the following: one-step process, cascade reaction, mild operation conditions, the generation of a “drop in” compound, and the use of a multifunctional catalyst [6–8]. The butadiene synthesis mechanism from ethanol is well accepted by many authors. It can be described as following: firstly, ethanol is dehydrogenated to acetaldehyde, then this aldehyde condenses and generates acetaldol which dehydrates to crotonaldehyde; next, this aldehyde is hydrogenated to crotyl alcohol by ethanol (MPV reaction) forming acetaldehyde; finally, the C4 alcohol dehydrate to butadiene. This mechanism is named as Toussaint-Kagan mechanism [2–5]. However, it is important to stress that in general the active sites associated to this mechanism are poorly described. Despite of this mechanism being well accepted in the literature, there are some other interesting propositions [2–5]. For instance, Qi et al., studying the butadiene synthesis from ethanol using Zn and Y on beta zeolite, proposed that the acetaldehyde and ethanol condense and generate 1,3-butanediol which dehydrates to crotyl alcohol [9]. In this case the MPV reaction is not needed. Sushkevich & Ivanova employing AgZr/SiO2 found that the acetaldehyde condensation occurs via Eley-Rideal mechanism, in which one of the aldehydes is in the gas phase [10]. Chagas et al. suggested that when Zn substitutes Zr in the ZrO2 lattice oxygen, vacancies are formed and they behave as strong basic sites in the dehydrogenation of ethanol [11]. Taking into account the scientific articles related to butadiene synthesis from ethanol published between 2010 and 2021 (Fig. 1 ), it was inferred that Mg, Zr, Zn, Cu, Ag and Si are the most frequent elements used in the catalyst's preparations. Silicon, employed mainly as SiO2, is almost in all catalyst formulations. Thus, it was excluded from Fig. 1. Zn, Cu and Ag are associated with the acetaldehyde generation, being Zn the most frequent. The Mg and Zr elements are related to the others steps of the butadiene synthesis from ethanol. Therefore, this work will be focused on the ZnZr/SiO2 catalyst; one of the most frequently studied systems. Larina et al. using Zn, Zr and SiO2 based catalysts, suggested that the acid sites predominance increases the activity and selectivity to butadiene of the catalysts [12]. On the other hand, Yang et al. associated the performance of the butadiene synthesis catalysts with the Zr dispersion on SBA-15 and the Zr-O-Si bond generation [13]. Miyazawa et al. employing DFT calculations and also experimental data proposed that there is no synergy between the ZnO and ZrO2 oxides [14]. Indeed, they suggested that ZnO and ZrO2 act cooperatively, in other words, in tandem in the different steps of this synthesis. The butadiene synthesis was analysed by Han et al. using ZrO2-SiO2 catalysts prepared by sol-gel procedure and employing a mixture of ethanol and acetaldehyde as reagents [15].They suggested that the performance of the catalyst is associated with the high dispersion of ZrO2 on SiO2 and the presence of Lewis acid sites on the catalyst surface. Gao et al. employing ZrO2 and nano SiO2 reached high selectivities to butadiene and associated the results to the presence of weak acid–basic sites [16]. According to the authors, the acid–basic properties of the catalysts are directly associated with the catalytic performance. As can be observed, acid and basic properties, the Zr dispersion on SiO2 and also the presence of Zr-O-Si bonds are associated with the performance of ZnZr/SiO2 or Zr/SiO2 in the butadiene synthesis. Indeed, the role of each catalyst's component is not well defined in the literature. Thus, the main objective of this contribution is the identification of the ZnZr/SiO2 active sites and the description of these species’ role in the mechanism of butadiene synthesis from ethanol. 2 Methodology 2.1 Catalysts preparation The catalysts were prepared by dry impregnation method. The SiO2 oxide provided by NorPro Saint-Gobain (200 m2g−1) was impregnated employing an ZrO(NO3) aqueous solution, dried at 110ºC overnight and calcined at 500ºC for 4 h (10ºCmin−1) under synthetic airflow (60 mLmin−1). The obtained solid was named as Zr/SiO2. After that, the Zr/SiO2 was impregnated using a Zn(NO3)2 aqueous solution, dried and calcined under the same conditions described above. The obtained solid was named as ZnZr/SiO2. The metal concentrations were 2.5 at.% and 0.7 at.% for Zr and Zn, respectively. 2.2 Characterization The surface areas were determined by adsorption and desorption of N2 using the BET method employing Micromeritics ASAP 2010 equipment. The samples were dried at 100ºC for 12 h and vacuum treated at 350ºC for 4 h. Then, N2 was adsorbed at −196ºC. The temperature-programmed desorption of isopropanol (isopropanol-TPD) followed by mass spectroscopy (MS) was carried out using a fixed bed reactor coupled to a QMG Prisma Plus mass spectrometer, Pfeiffer Vacuum GmbH. Isopropanol vapor was generated by passing He through a saturator at room temperature. The sample (250 mg) was pretreated at 500ºC for 1 h (10ºCmin−1) under synthetic airflow (50 mLmin−1). The adsorption was carried out at 50ºC for 1 h under isopropanol/He flow (20 mLmin−1) and the desorption from 50 to 500ºC (20ºCmin−1) under He flow (80 mLmin−1), remaining at 500ºC for 30 min. The fragments m/z = 45 (isopropanol), m/z = 58 (acetone) and m/z = 40 (propene) were continuously monitored. The fragments were mathematically treated to eliminate contributions of more than one species. The temperature programmed surface reaction of ethanol (ethanol-TPSR) followed by mass spectroscopy (MS) was conducted employing a microreactor coupled to a QMG 220 Prisma Plus Mass Spectrometer, Pfeiffer Vacuum GmbH. The catalyst (250 mg) was submitted to pretreatment at 500ºC (10ºCmin−1) for 1 h under synthetic airflow (50 mLmin−1). Ethanol vapor was generated by passing He through a saturator at 32ºC. The adsorption was carried out at 50ºC for 1 h under ethanol/He flow (20 mLmin−1) and desorption from 50 to 500ºC (20ºCmin−1) under He flow (80 mLmin−1), remaining at 500ºC for 30 min. The following fragments were continuously monitored by the mass spectrometer: m/z = 2 (hydrogen), m/z = 18 (water), m/z = 26 (ethene), m/z = 29 (acetaldehyde), m/z = 31 (ethanol), m/z = 38 (propene), m/z = 54 (butadiene), m/z = 56 (isobutene), m/z = 44 (carbon dioxide) and m/z = 16 (methane). The fragments were mathematically treated to eliminate contributions of more than one species. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution image (HRTEM) were obtained in a Jeol JEM 2100F operating at 200 kV. Elemental mapping analysis was carried out with an Oxford EDX detector, which allows EDX experiments to be performed in the scanning transmission mode (STEM). Samples were suspended in ethanol and dispersed ultrasonically for 5 min. Drops of the suspension were deposited on a copper grid (#200) coated with a holey carbon film. Particle size measurements were performed using Image-J (1.52a). More than 100 particles were considered for statistical purpose. ZnZr/SiO2 catalyst was also embedded in Spurr's resin at ambient temperature, followed by polymerization at 80 °C for 12 h. Ultra-thin sections of 50 nm were cut with an ultramicrotome (PT-PC/RMC Boeckeler). The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded at room temperature using the X-band cavity frequency (9 GHz) in an EMX Plus Bruker spectrometer employing a microwave power, modulation amplitude and modulation frequency of 20 mW, 5 G and 100 KHz, respectively. The broad lines were fitted with derivative Lorentzian lines and the areas were calculated as I∙(ΔH)2 where I and ΔH are intensity and linewidth of derivative curves, respectively. Signals in the high field region with g-values abroad to the free electron (2.0024) were simulated using the easy spin routine from MATLAB software. The catalysts (100 mg) were submitted to the following pretreatment: firstly, they were dried at 150ºC (10ºCmin−1) for 30 min under an argon flow (40mLmin−1); then, reduced with 20% H2/Ar (50 mLmin−1) for 1 h at 500 ºC (10ºCmin−1); finally, cooled to room temperature under Ar flow (40 mLmin−1). After treatment the samples were sealed in the reactor and conducted to the equipment. The compositions and chemical environments of the surface of samples were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Analyses were performed by using a hemispherical spectrometer PHOIBOS 150 - SPECS, equipped with X-ray gun (XR-50 with Al Kα source (1486.6 eV). The binding energy shifts due to surface charging were corrected through the use of the C 1 s level at 284.6 eV, as an internal standard. Spectra were Shirley background-subtracted across the energy region fitted using CasaXPS version 2.3.16 PR 1.6. The base pressure in the analysis chamber was kept in the range 5 × 10−8 Pa to 1 × 10−7 Pa. The samples were analyzed with 50 eV pass-through energy, 1 step and 15 scans, for the survey spectrum. For the regions of interest, it was used 20 eV as pass-through energy, 0.08 step and at least 25 scans. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed in an Empyrean diffractometer from Malvern Panalytical, equipped with a PIXcel3D detector and Cu Kα (1.5406 Å) radiation. The diffractometer was operated at 45 kV and 40 mA and the diffraction patterns were obtained at room temperature, from 10° to 90°, with a step size of 0.013° and 0.1 s per step. Raman spectra of the prepared catalysts were obtained employing a micro-Raman microscope (HORIBA Jobin Yvon, model XploRA), at the exciting wavelengths of 638 and 532 nm. The laser excitation beam was focused onto the powder samples with an intensity of 25 W/mm2 by a 10x objective lens. The scans were performed using a fixed acquisition time of 5 s with 20 accumulations, with a range between 25 and 1200 cm−1 and a spectral resolution of 4 cm−1. The scattered light was dispersed using a holographic grating with 600 lines mm−1 and collected by a Si-based charge-coupled device (CCD) detector cooled by liquid nitrogen. The spectrometer was calibrated by using the 520.4 cm−1 peak of crystal a silicon wafer. UV–VIS diffuse reflectance spectra were obtained in the range of 200–500 nm employing a Varian Cary 5 spectrometer using a Harrick diffuse reflectance accessory with Praying Mantis geometry. Barium sulfate was used as a reference. 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalytic tests were carried out using a conventional system with a fixed bed reactor (PFR reactor). The catalysts (ZnZr/SiO2 and Zr/SiO2) were initially dried at 150 °C for 30 min under N2 flow (77 mLmin−1). Then, the solids were calcined at 500 °C for 1 h under synthetic airflow (60 mLmin−1). The catalysts were cooled and purged for 10 min under N2 flow (77 mLmin−1). Ethanol vapors were generated by passing a N2 flow through a saturator. The products of the reaction were analyzed online for 4 h using a GC Agilent 7890 instrument equipped with TCD and FID detectors. Isoconversion catalytic tests (70%) were carried out at 385 °C and employed the following gaseous mixture N2: C2H5OH=97:3 vol%. The space velocities were 3.39 gEtOHgcat −1h−1 and 0.34 gEtOHgcat −1h−1 for ZnZr/SiO2 and Zr/SiO2, respectively. Test employing Zn/SiO2, ZnZr/SiO2 and Zr/SiO2 at 0.85 gEtOHgcat −1h−1 and same conditions described above were also carried out. Other tests were performed varying the contact time and temperature for ZnZr/SiO2 catalyst. The ethanol conversion was defined as the ratio between the ethanol moles consumed to the moles of ethanol introduced in the feed. The definition of the selectivity to one specific compound is the ratio between the number of ethanol moles consumed to synthesize this compound to the total number of ethanol moles consumed. 2.4 Computational methodology Theoretical spin-polarized DFT calculations were conducted with the plane-wave-based codes of the Quantum Espresso package. Core-valence electron interactions were described using ultrasoft pseudopotential. Electronic exchange and correlation contributions were obtained through the semi-local formulation of Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof [17]. As the modeling of metal-grafted amorphous silica is challenging due to the non-homogeneous site distribution [18], the models used here to investigate the elementary reaction steps of butadiene synthesis were based on a silsesquioxane geometry. This system has been applied successfully in works involving, e.g., CC coupling [19,20] and alcohol oxidation reactions [21]. The model used to mimic the isolated Zr site ((Si-O)3-Zr-OH), shown in Fig S1(a), is similar to those of Shylesh et al. [20], while the one used for the Zn site is slightly different (Fig. S1(b)) preserving Zn in coordination two (Si-O-Zn-O-Si) vicinal to a silanol group (not directly connected) [22]. The calculations were conducted by placing the models and adsorbates into a large periodic cubic box of 25 Å in each cartesian direction, which included long-range electrostatic corrections for non-periodic systems [23], and is enough to ensure that the systems are isolated. All atoms within the box were relaxed without any kind of constraint during the geometry optimization until the atomic forces have converged to 0.001 Ry/Bohr and the variation of the total energy between two consecutive iterations was on the order of 0.0001 Ry. Grimme's DFT-D correction method was applied to incorporate the van der Waals interactions throughout all calculations [24]. In order to check the accuracy of this computation setup, further tests were done using a larger (30 Å edge) box, however negligible differences were found in the geometric parameters. The Brillouin-zone integration was done using a single k-point (Γ point). The Kohn-Sham electronic valence states were expanded in plane waves up to cutoff energy of 50 Ry (1 Ry ∼13.61 eV), while 400 Ry were used for charge density cutoff. The Climbing-image Nudged Elastic Band (CI-NEB) method was employed to determine energy barriers and transition states [25], where nine images were considered between the initial and final states. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 2 exhibits the catalytic behavior of Zr/SiO2 and ZnZr/SiO2 at the same space velocity (0.85 gEtOHgcat −1h−1) and ethanol as a reagent. Butadiene and acetaldehyde are the main compounds generated when the ZnZr/SiO2 catalyst is employed, whereas, using the Zr/SiO2 catalyst ethene is the major product. Ethyl ether, propene, butenes and butanol (not shown) are synthesized by both catalysts at low selectivity. The Zr/SiO2 catalyst also promotes the generation of heavy compounds. The Zn/SiO2 was also tested at these conditions and the only product observed was acetaldehyde. Adding Zn to ZrO2 the selectivity to butadiene is multiplied by 10. Furthermore, the Zr based catalysts were tested at isoconversion (70%). This conversion was reached employing 3.39 gEtOHgcat −1h−1 and 0.34 gEtOHgcat −1h−1 space velocities for the ZnZr/SiO2 and Zr/SiO2 catalysts, respectively. The selectivities to butadiene and ethene of ZnZr/SiO2 were 23 and 4%, respectively and employing the Zr/SiO2 catalyst these selectivities were 11 and 48%. Thus, the addition of Zn to Zr/SiO2 not only improves the selectivity to butadiene but also the catalytic activity. Considering the butadiene synthesis mechanism described in the introduction section, it can be inferred that the theoretical selectivity ratio between butadiene and acetaldehyde is 2. Indeed, the MPV reaction generates not only the crotyl alcohol but also acetaldehyde. The ratio value obtained employing the ZnZr/SiO2 catalytic tests is 1.8, showing that almost all acetaldehyde generated by ethanol dehydrogenation is transformed into butadiene by this catalyst. Figs. 3 and 4 depict the catalytic behavior of the ZnZrO2/SiO2 catalyst at different temperatures and space velocities, respectively. It can be observed as temperature increases the conversion increases, the acetaldehyde selectivity decreases, whereas the selectivity to butadiene goes through a maximum at 385 °C and selectivity to ethene slightly increases. In accordance with the butadiene mechanism described above, as the space velocity increases, the selectivity to butadiene decreases, whereas the selectivity to acetaldehyde increases. It can also be observed that full ethanol conversion and the highest selectivity to butadiene (64%) were reached at 0.28 gEtOHgcat −1h−1. Furthermore, decreasing the residence time the selectivity to ethene does not change. The butadiene synthesis from ethanol is a cascade reaction, in which the competition between dehydration versus dehydrogenation of this alcohol occurs in the first step [11]. Aiming to better describe the behavior of the prepared catalysts in the first step of this synthesis, the competition among propene (dehydration) and acetone (dehydrogenation) generation from isopropanol was analysed by isopropanol-TPD (Scheme 1 ). In order to avoid by-products, ethanol was substituted by isopropanol. The dehydrogenation of the later generates acetone which is less reactive than acetaldehyde. Fig. 5a and b depict propene and acetone spectra of the isopropanol-TPD, respectively. Fig. 5a and b depict that the Zr-based catalysts form propene and a very low amount of acetone. Adding Zn to Zr/SiO2 the amount of propene generated decreases and the one of acetone increases. Table 1 exhibits the ratio between acetone and propene amount synthesized during the isopropanol-TPD. The result shows that ZnZr/SiO2 catalyst is more prone to generate acetone than Zr/SiO2. Thus, by adding Zn to Zr/SiO2 the dehydrogenation properties of this catalyst are boosted. Some mechanisms have been suggested for alcohol dehydration being E2 one of them [26]. It occurs via a concerted mechanism that involves pairs of Lewis acid and basic sites, being the former strong. The mechanism can be described as following: firstly, the O of the hydroxyl and the H of the β-C interact with the acid and basic pair, respectively and simultaneously; then, the OH and H react generating H2O and ethene is formed. The alcohol dehydrogenation requires weak acid and strong basic sites [26]. The mechanism can be described as following: firstly, the alcohol interacts with the Lewis acid and basic sites generating alkoxide species; then, the α-H of the alkoxide species is abstracted by the basic site forming an aldehyde or ketone. Fig. 6 and Table 1 depict the acid properties of SiO2, Zr/SiO2 and ZnZr/SiO2. The SiO2 oxide almost does not show acid properties, whereas both Zr-based catalysts show almost the same number and strength of the acid sites. Taking into account that Zr atoms on the surface are the acid sites, this result suggests that by adding Zn to the Zr/SiO2 catalyst the Zr species on SiO2 does not change. Moreover, there is no interaction between Zn and Zr species. However, by adding Zn to Zr/SiO2 the acetone generation increases whereas propene decreases (Fig. 5a and b , Table 1). Thus, it can be suggested that Zn promotes the dehydrogenation reaction, and consequently the generation of strong basic sites on the SiO2 oxide. The Raman spectra (638 nm) of ZnZr/SiO2, Zr/SiO2, ZnO, ZrO2 and SiO2 are depicted in Fig. 7 . The ZnZr/SiO2 and the Zr/SiO2 spectra are very similar to the one of SiO2. Therefore, it is not possible to infer the presence of ZnO and ZrO2 nor identify vibrations related to other Zr or Zn compounds. This result suggests that Zn and Zr species are highly dispersed on SiO2 surface. When employing the exciting wavelength 532 nm the same results were observed. The lower number of vacancies exhibited by ZnZr/SiO2 is related to the preparation procedure. Again, this behavior is in line with the isopropanol-TPD results. 4 Theoretical examination of the butadiene synthesis mechanism In short, the present theoretical study aims at investigating how Zn and Zr species dispersed on SiO2 as well as ZrO2 nanoparticles supported on SiO2 are capable of promoting the generation of butadiene from ethanol through a Toussaint-Kagan-like mechanism [2–5] . In accordance with the experiments, it was assumed that, besides ZrO2 nanoparticles which are present on both Zr/SiO2 and ZnZr/SiO2 catalysts, isolated Zn and Zr species are likely also formed during the catalyst preparation so that their presence under reaction conditions as active sites could not be ignored. In this sense, an ethanol-to-butadiene reaction mechanism was proposed and assessed via DFT calculations. It was divided into two distinct cycles (see Scheme 2 ). The first cycle assumes the presence of Zn (Figure S1b), where ethanol adsorbs and is dehydrogenated to acetaldehyde. In principle, this cycle determines the important role played by Zn sites, that is, to increase the production of acetaldehyde for further CC coupling reactions. The calculations show that these further steps are unfavorable on Zn species (Table S4) and therefore they occur on independent Zr sites. According to the proposed pathway, the second cycle (Scheme 2) involves the participation of Zr species, with Zr either confined in the SiO2 support as isolated species (Figure S1a) or as a nanoparticle (Figure S1c). Acetaldehyde adsorbs and condense on these species to give acetaldol (3-hydroxybutanal). In turn, this C4 compound dehydrates to crotonaldehyde releasing one of the Zr bonds where a sacrificial ethanol may adsorb. This alcohol interacts with crotonaldehyde reducing it to crotyl alcohol via MPV hydrogenation. Finally, the alcohol dehydrates to produce butadiene. Thorough calculations were carried out aiming to shed light on the nature of the possible active sites and also providing a reasonable comparison between the theoretical systems and the experimental data. The DFT study starts with a careful examination of the reaction steps over isolated sites (Section 4.1) and subsequently investigates them on a ZrO2 nanoparticle model (Section 4.2). 4.1 Ethanol-to-butadiene reaction over isolated sites As the generation of acetaldehyde is crucial to the butadiene synthesis, it was examined firstly. The reaction energy diagram over isolated Zn is depicted in Figure S4, while the corresponding geometries of initial, transition and final states are shown in Table S1. The process starts with the adsorption of ethanol on the Zn site, found exothermic (−0.78 eV) although non-dissociative. The next step is the formation of an ethoxy species through the cleavage of the OH bond; this reaction has a moderate activation energy (0.87 eV) and endothermic reaction energy (+0.47). Finally, an α-H is removed to form acetaldehyde and H2; this step has a higher kinetic barrier (1.48 eV) being also rather endothermic (+0.63 eV). Further calculations (not shown) revealed that the direct generation of acetaldehyde (without the ethoxy formation) is less favorable kinetically suggesting that prior formation of ethoxy makes the α-H more acidic. For comparison, the same reaction steps over the Zr isolated site were carried out (geometries are shown in Table S2; see also Fig. S4 for the energy diagram). It can be seen that, although the activation barrier to form ethoxy species (step 2) was slightly lower on Zr (0.48 eV), the formation of acetaldehyde (step 3) has a higher kinetic barrier (1.89 eV) than compared with the Zn isolated species. In principle, this confirms that acetaldehyde forms faster on isolated Zn species, although it could not be completely ruled out the formation of this aldehyde on Zr. It means that the amount of acetaldehyde greatly increases in the presence of Zn and both sites work in tandem to form butadiene. This result is in good agreement with the catalytic tests results and ethanol-TPD spectra. The next elementary steps, i.e., the formation of enolate species from acetaldehyde and further (aldol) steps on the way to form butadiene will take place preferentially over Zr. To reinforce this point, the generation of enolate through the abstraction of an acetaldehyde α-H by a basic site was investigated for both Zn and Zr sites (see Table S4). The theoretical results show that the kinetic barrier on Zn (> 2 eV) is substantially higher than on Zr (0.66 eV), which clearly indicates that enolate, an important aldol intermediate, forms preferentially on Zr sites. Therefore, these results support our previous assumption that condensation steps occur over Zr sites, while higher rates of acetaldehyde formation occur favorably over Zn. This result is in line with the catalytic behavior of Zn/SiO2 which generates almost only acetaldehyde. Accordingly, the subsequent aldol steps were investigated only over isolated Zr. The full energy diagram is depicted in Fig. 13 and the corresponding geometries of all elementary steps are shown in Table S5. Right after an enolate species is formed, a second acetaldehyde molecule interacts exothermically (−0.89 eV) with the Zr site (step 3, Table S5). After that, both acetaldehyde and enolate undergo an energetically favorable coupling reaction to form 3- hydroxybutanal (acetaldol); the low barrier (0.17 eV) suggests that this step is rapid. Then, crotonaldehyde forms endothermically through dehydration of acetaldol (+0.33 eV, step 5). In the next step (Step 6), the adsorption of ethanol was found energetically favorable (−0.42 eV). From this point, the MPV process starts with the transfer of the ethanol proton to the Zr hydroxyl (step 7). Then, an α-H transfers endothermically to crotonaldehyde resulting in a crotoxy intermediate. This step has a barrier of 1.02 eV and releases an extra acetaldehyde molecule. Next, the formation of crotyl alcohol was found slightly endothermic (+0.15 eV) with a barrier of 1.03 eV (step 9). Regarding the last elementary step, that is, the dehydration of crotyl alcohol to generate butadiene, it was the most difficult to manage. As a first approach it was divided into two steps: in the first one the COH bond of crotyl alcohol would break forming 1-butene, whereas in the second step a CH bond of the methyl group would ideally cleave resulting butadiene. It turns out that during the first step, once the DFT geometry optimization process ended, even after several attempts, the OH group migrated back spontaneously reforming crotyl alcohol; as will be shown in the next section, it is different on a ZrO2 nanoparticle. Thus, it was assumed that butadiene forms from crotyl alcohol through a step in which COH and methyl CH bonds cleave concomitantly (Table S5 – step 10). According with the calculations this step is rate-limiting due to the highest kinetic barrier (1.83 eV). Finally, the release of butadiene to the gas phase closes the catalytic cycle and gives back the free catalytic site. Notice that up to TS-6 the steps of Fig. 13 are rigorously the same, but from this point on there is a small difference regarding the direct (isolated Zr) and indirect (ZrO2 NP) formation of butadiene from crotyl alcohol. Another possible mechanism, i.e., the nucleophilic addition was also investigated; this path does not involve MPV steps [34,35]. The calculations (not shown) indicated that the rate-limiting activation barrier is higher than the aldol condensation. So, it can be assumed that the butadiene molecules are formed preferentially via aldol steps on isolated sites of the ZnZr/SiO2 catalyst. 4.2 Ethanol-to-butadiene reaction over ZrO2 nanoparticles The proposed reaction mechanism over isolated Zr sites is plausible. However, the experiments are unambiguous about the presence of ZrO2 nanoparticles on SiO2 surface (Fig. 11). Therefore, it is crucial to understand how they are contributing to the butadiene formation. As the chemical structure of ZrO2 nanoparticles is not unique, a great number configurations are possible. Thus, the present calculations were based on a set of systems proposed by the Pacchioni group [36] which have been well established for their use in catalysis modeling. Accordingly, a Zr16O32 model (Figure S1c) was employed to investigate the aldol condensation mechanism. It is important mentioning that, apart from minor differences, the elementary steps investigated here were essentially the same as those considered for the Zr single-site; the DFT technicalities were also similar (see Section 2.4). Firstly, it was examined whether the formation of acetaldehyde from ethanol would be kinetically more favorable on ZrO2 particle when compared with the Zn single-site, as proposed in Scheme 2- 1st cycle. Interestingly, the adsorption of ethanol over the nanoparticle (Table S3) was found considerably more exothermic (−1.30 eV) comparing with both Zn and Zr single-atom models, although also non-dissociative with respect to the OH bond. The calculations show that the generation of acetaldehyde on the ZrO2 nanoparticle is kinetically less favorable due to a higher barrier (2.01 eV) regarding the rate-limiting step (see Figure S4). Furthermore, the removal of acetaldehyde (plus H2) from the nanoparticle to the gas phase is energy-consuming, suggesting that this step is energetically less favorable. Indeed, these results are in qualitative agreement with the present experimental data, which clearly indicate that the Zr/SiO2 catalyst, which show high concentration of ZrO2 nanoparticles, produces mainly ethene and relatively lower amounts of acetaldehyde and butadiene at 385 °C (Fig. 2). It also agrees with the ethanol-TPD (Fig. 12) which evidences that acetaldehyde is produced over the Zr/SiO2 catalyst at much higher temperature compared with ZnZr/SiO2. Most importantly, these results reinforce the main role played by Zn sites and give support to our previous hypothesis in which acetaldehyde forms preferentially over the ZnZr/SiO2 catalyst. It is necessary also to examine through DFT the catalytic properties of the ZrO2 nanoparticle regarding the proposed mechanism site (Scheme 2- 2nd cycle). The complete illustration of the aldol steps on the ZrO2 nanoparticle is shown Table S6, whereas the corresponding reaction energy diagram is depicted in Fig. 13. The first step was assumed as the same as those for the Zr single-atom, that is, the adsorption of acetaldehyde. It was found more exothermic (−2.05 eV) than on the isolated systems. It is interesting to notice that in this case the subsequent formation of enolate already represents the rate-limiting step, with a barrier of 2.05 eV. As the reaction continues, a second acetaldehyde adsorbs and couples with enolate to form acetaldol. This step is very favorable (−1.43 eV) and almost barrierless (0.04 eV). Subsequently, the acetaldol dehydration occurs to give crotonaldehyde (step 5). It is endothermic (+0.88 eV) and has a kinetic barrier of 1.46 eV, comparable with the same step over Zr single-site model (1.42 eV). In the sequence, a sacrificial ethanol adsorbs initializing the MPV process. The calculations indicate that the adsorption of this ethanol is slightly unfavorable (+0.12 eV), although the subsequent formation of ethoxide (OH cleavage) is kinetically (0.15 eV) and energetically (−0.32 eV) favorable. It is followed by an α-H migration towards the crotonaldehyde carbonyl C atom to form crotyl alkoxide (Table S6 – step 8). The calculations showed it has a barrier of 1.06 eV. The subsequent formation of crotyl alcohol was found endothermic (+0.77 eV) with a barrier of 1.53 eV. The ultimate step is the dehydration of crotyl alcohol to generate butadiene. As mentioned, this step is slightly different on the ZrO2 nanoparticle comparing with the isolated Zr species (Section 4.1). Here, the calculations indicate that butadiene is generated within two steps: the first one has a relatively low barrier of 0.62 eV (Table S6 – step 10) and is exothermic by −1.09 eV, resulting an adsorbed 1-butene. Interestingly, butene have been detected in the present experiments only at very low selectivity (Section 3), an indicative that the system prefers to form butadiene. Indeed, the calculations show that the barrier to cleave the methyl CH bond and form butadiene is moderate (1.18 eV), which means that this step is not rate-limiting. The catalytic cycle is closed when butadiene and H2O are released to the gas phase. 4.3 Some remarks Many characterization techniques were employed in this work in order to describe the catalysts. All these techniques generate relevant pieces of information. However, all of them show significant limitations. The ZrO2 nanoparticles (monoclinic) can be observed by HRTEM. However, due to SiO2 amorphism it is not possible to observe the Zr disperse species. ZrO2 and Zn disperse species on SiO2 surface were observed by XPS. Nevertheless, due to the Zr3d spectra characteristic the presence of the Zr disperse species were indirectly inferred. Using the UV–VIS reflectance diffuse spectroscopy is possible to identify ZrO2 and the Zr disperse species. However, this technique is not capable of generating quantitative data. The XRD and Raman spectroscopy are not able to show the small ZrO2 nanoparticles and the Zr and Zn disperse species. Thus, using all these characterization techniques it is possible to infer the presence of ZrO2 (monoclinic) nanoparticles, Zr and Zn disperse species on SiO2 surface. The Zn-ZrO2 interaction is well described in the literature for the ZnxZr1−xO2− y mixed oxides [11,27,31]. Indeed, Zn+2 substitutes Zr+4 in the ZrO2 lattice generating oxygen vacancies and coordinatively unsaturated Zr4+ ions (cus). Thus, the Zn-Zr interaction could be suggest for the ZnZr/SiO2 catalyst. However, the EPR data does not show an increase of the number of vacancies when Zn is added to ZrO2/SiO2. Moreover, Zr 3d5/2 XPS binding energy does not change when Zn is added to Zr/SiO2 and the Zn 2p3/2 XPS binding energy of Zn/SiO2 is similar to the one of ZnZr/SiO2. Furthermore, the interplanar spacing of the ZrO2 nanoparticle (monoclinic) obtained by HRTEM does not show changes regarding the insertion of Zn into ZrO2 lattice. Thus, Zn and ZrO2 nanoparticle interaction seems not to occur. However, due to the limitation of the techniques employed, the Zn interaction with the Zr disperse species on SiO2 cannot be ruled out. The catalytic test results, isopropanol-TPD and ethanol-TPD exhibit that Zn promotes the ethanol dehydrogenation. Indeed, the catalyst containing Zn (ZnZr/SiO2) is fairly more active and selective to butadiene than Zr/SiO2. According the DFT calculations the generation of acetaldehyde over Zn species is energetically and kinetically more favorable than over Zr isolated species or ZrO2. As described above only two Zr species were identify by the characterization techniques on the ZnZr/SiO2 and Zr/SiO2 catalysts. They are the Zr disperse species and ZrO2 nanoparticles. The XPS data suggest that ZrO2 nanoparticles are in higher concentration on the SiO2 surface than the disperse ones. The calculations show that the Zr disperse species tend to be somewhat more active than ZrO2 nanoparticles due to an overall lower kinetic barrier regarding the rate-limiting step. Nevertheless, such difference in rate-limiting barriers is not outstandingly large (1.83 eV vs. 2.05 eV). Interestingly, this step is not the same. In the case of the isolated Zr species it is related with a dehydration reaction and for the nanoparticle is the enolate synthesis. All in all, from a rational catalyst design perspective, even within a relatively small difference of rate-limiting barriers between the systems under study it could be assumed that an increase in the surface density of isolated Zr sites would result a more active catalyst. 5 Conclusion Using many characterization techniques, it was possible to identify the following species on the SiO2 surface: ZrO2 (monoclinic) nanoparticles, Zr and Zn disperse species. EPR, XPS, and HRTEM showed that there is no interaction between ZrO2 nanoparticles and Zn disperse species. However, due to the limitations of the techniques employed, the interaction between Zn and Zr disperse species cannot be ruled out. The isopropanol-TPD, ethanol-TPD and the catalytic tests showed that Zn of ZnZr/SiO2 inhibits ethanol dehydration, promotes the ethanol dehydrogenation and butadiene synthesis. The DFT results exhibits that the acetaldehyde generation on Zn disperse species shows a lower kinetic barrier than on ZrO2 or Zr disperse species. Therefore, the main role of Zn is to promote de first step of this cascade reaction. The DFT calculations also show that both ZrO2 and Zr disperse species are able to transform acetaldehyde into butadiene, being the latter somewhat more active. Thus, butadiene is synthetized from ethanol on ZrO2 nanoparticles, Zn and Zr disperse species which are components of the ZnZr/SiO2 catalyst. CRediT authorship contribution statement Luciano H.
